page.title: 08Trees and Hedgerows
page.content: The commonest tree around Cogges and Witney is the Willow. This tree grows along both banks of the River Windrush and all the trees have been pollarded in the past. The willow wood is no longer needed for hurdle making or for thatching corn ricks and so now they are only pollarded to prevent them from growing too big so branches break off. Many of the hedgerows which divided up the fields have been removed over the last ten or so years to enlarge fields for the large machinery. This is most often where grain is grown. All that is left of these hedges is an occasional oak tree which has been left standing. There are still a few dead elm trees standing, (+ 1 alive) but mostly only pieces of trunk lie around. In hedges we found mostly hawthorn, briar, sloe, bramble. The wildest hedgerows were on the abandoned railway track.
